data.title: Grand Duchess Olga Alexandrovna (1882-1960)
data.meta_description:
Olga  was the youngest child of Emperor Alexander III of Russia and Empress Maria Feodorovna (née Princess Dagmar of Denmark.  Her older brother was Emperor Nicholas II.
	
	She was raised at the Gatchina Palace outside Saint Petersburg. Olga's relationship with her mother, Empress Marie, the daughter of King Christian IX of Denmark, was strained and distant from childhood. In contrast, she and her father were close. He died when she was 12, and her brother Nicholas became emperor.
	
	In 1901, she married Duke Peter Alexandrovich of Oldenburg but the marriage was  annulled by the Emperor in October 1916.  She then married cavalry officer Nikolai Kulikovsky, with whom she had fallen in love several years before, and they had two sons.  
	
	After escaping revolutionary Russia in 1920, Olga and her husband and children joined her mother, the Dowager Empress, in Denmark.  Olga acted as companion and secretary to her mother, and was often sought out by Romanov impostors who claimed to be her dead relatives. She met Anna Anderson, the best-known impostor, in Berlin in 1925.
	
	Olga died in Toronto, Ontario, Canada in 1960.
data.text:
Olga was the youngest child of Emperor Alexander III of Russia and Empress Maria Feodorovna (née Princess Dagmar of Denmark. Her older brother was Emperor Nicholas II.

She was raised at the Gatchina Palace outside Saint Petersburg. Olga's relationship with her mother, Empress Marie, the daughter of King Christian IX of Denmark, was strained and distant from childhood. In contrast, she and her father were close. He died when she was 12, and her brother Nicholas became emperor.

In 1901, she married Duke Peter Alexandrovich of Oldenburg but the marriage was annulled by the Emperor in October 1916. She then married cavalry officer Nikolai Kulikovsky, with whom she had fallen in love several years before, and they had two sons.

After escaping revolutionary Russia in 1920, Olga and her husband and children joined her mother, the Dowager Empress, in Denmark. Olga acted as companion and secretary to her mother, and was often sought out by Romanov impostors who claimed to be her dead relatives. She met Anna Anderson, the best-known impostor, in Berlin in 1925.

Olga died in Toronto, Ontario, Canada in 1960.
